metadata.title: Spatiotemporal transcriptomics reveals pathogenesis of viral myocarditis

abstract.text: A significant fraction of sudden death in children and young adults is due to myocarditis, an 11 inflammatory disease of the heart, most often caused by viral infection. Here we used 12 integrated single-cell and spatial transcriptomics to create a high-resolution, spatially resolved 13 map of reovirus-induced myocarditis in neonatal murine hearts. We assayed hearts collected 14 at three timepoints after reovirus infection and studied the temporal, spatial, and cellular 15 heterogeneity of host-virus interactions. We further assayed the intestine, the primary site of 16 reovirus infection to establish a full chronology of molecular events that ultimately lead to 17 myocarditis. We implemented targeted enrichment of viral transcripts to establish the cellular 18 targets of the virus in the intestine and the heart. Our data give insight into the cell-type 19 specificity of innate immune responses, and into the transcriptional states of inflamed cardiac 20 cells that recruit circulating immune cells, including cytotoxic T cells which induce pyroptosis in 21 the myocarditic tissue. Analyses of spatially restricted gene expression in myocarditic regions 22 and the border zone around those regions identified immune-mediated cell-type specific injury 23 and stress responses. Overall, we observe a dynamic and complex network of cellular 24 phenotypes and cell-cell interactions associated with viral myocarditis. 25 26

body_text.text: INTRODUCTION 27 Viral infection is the most common cause of myocarditis 1,2 . The resulting inflammatory 28 cardiomyopathy can lead to arrhythmias, dilated cardiomyopathy, and death 1,3,4 . In humans, 29 viral myocarditis is challenging to study because of the low sensitivity of available diagnostic 30 testing, the acute onset of the disease, the focal nature of the disease, and the extreme 31 heterogeneity of immune-virus interactions in complex cardiac tissues 4-6 . In mice, mammalian 32 orthoreovirus offers a flexible model system 7 . After oral inoculation, the Type 1 Lang (T1L) 33 reovirus strain initially infects the gastrointestinal tract. Within days the infection then spreads 34 to secondary sites in the body, including the heart, leading to myocarditis in up to 50% of 35 infections 7-9 . Yet, even in this mouse model, the molecular pathogenesis of viral myocarditis is 36 difficult to study because of the complex network of cardiac and immune cell types involved 37 and the cellular, spatial, and temporal heterogeneity of the disease 2,10 . Consequently, neither 38 the cell types that are responsible for the innate immune response, nor the cell types that are within infected cardiac tissues is needed to address these knowledge gaps. 47 Here we used integrated single-cell and spatially resolved RNA-sequencing (RNA-seq) to 48 study the cellular and spatial heterogeneity of myocarditic processes in the hearts of reovirus- 49 infected neonatal mice at multiple time points after infection. After oral438    inoculation, reovirus T1L infects entero-endocrine and enterocyte cells in the gut epithelium439    within 1 dpi. These cells mount a potent innate immune response to inhibit viral replication.440    The virus then infects the gut lymphatic cells within 4 dpi and is transmitted via lymphatics to 441 the bloodstream and then to secondary sites in the body, including the heart. Around 4 dpi, the442 virus infects the endothelial cells lining the cardiac vasculature. Endothelial cells mount a 443 potent innate immune response in the heart. In symptomatic cases, inflamed endothelial cells 444 secrete chemokines that recruit circulating immune cells, including cytotoxic T cells. Tissue-445 infiltrating cytotoxic T cells then induce pyroptosis in the infected tissue inducing myocarditis. 446 Overall, our experiments reveal a dynamic and spatially heterogeneous network of cellular 447 phenotypes and cell-cell interactions associated with reovirus-induced myocarditis. 448 Integrated high-throughput scRNA-seq and spatial transcriptomics was recently used to study 449 heart development 32,33 and heart disease 30,34 , but these methods have not been used to study 450 viral myocarditis prior to our work. Bulk RNA-seq has been used previously to profile 451 transcriptomic signatures of infection, inflammation, and tissue injury associated with viral 452 myocarditis 9,35-38 . Yet, these ensemble-level approaches do not capture the cellular and spatial 453 heterogeneity of host response to infection. scRNA-seq has recently been used to study 454 Coxsackievirus B3 (CVB3)-induced myocarditis in a mouse model 39 . Lasrado et al. report 455 inflammatory phenotypes of myeloid cells, the role of fibroblasts in remodeling and 456 inflammation, and the role of cytotoxic T-cells in CVB3-induced myocarditis. These 461 viruses display a broad host range, but only young hosts develop the disease.
